title: Coningsby, or, The New Generation vol. 1
subject: Politicians--fiction; Great Britain--fiction
description: The novel follows the life and career of Henry Coningsby, the orphan grandson of a wealthy marquess, Lord Monmouth. Lord Monmouth initially disapproved of Coningsby's parents' marriage, but on their death he relents and sends the boy to be educated at Eton College. At Eton Coningsby meets and befriends Oswald Millbank, the son of a rich cotton manufacturer who is a bitter enemy of Lord Monmouth. The two older men represent old and new wealth in society. As Coningsby grows up he begins to develop his own liberal political views, and falls in love with Oswald's sister Edith. When Lord Monmouth discovers these developments he is furious and secretly disinherits his grandson. On his death, Coningsby is left penniless, and is forced to work for his living. He decides to study law and become a barrister. This proof of his character impresses Edith's father (who had previously also been hostile) and he consents to their marriage at last. By the end of the novel Coningsby is elected to Parliament for his new father-in-law's constituency and his fortune is restored.
creator: Benjamin Disraeli

title: Contarini Fleming, A Psychological Autobiography vol. 1
subject: Maternal deprivation--fiction; Depression, Mental--fiction; Self-realization--fiction; Venice (Italy)--fiction

title: Henrietta Temple, A Love Story vol. 1
subject: Aristocracy (Social class)--fiction; Upper class families--fiction; Dandies--fiction; London (England)--fiction
description: Disraeli wrote the first volume of Henrietta Temple in 1833 at the start of his affair with Henrietta Sykes, on whom the novels eponymous heroine is based, and completed it three years later, shortly after the affair had ended. The two volumes reflect these two stages of the relationship, the first with, "the rustle of real petticoats [being] more audible than in any other part of Disraeli's work," the latter where, "passion has vanished." The novel was written at a time when Disraeli was heavily in debt (ca 1m in todays terms) and its limited success helped ease Disraelis financial situation.
creator: Benjamin Disraeli

title: Henrietta Temple, A Love Story vol. 2
subject: Aristocracy (Social class)--fiction; Upper class families--fiction; Dandies--fiction; London (England)--fiction

subject: Aristocracy (Social class)--fiction; Upper class families--fiction; Dandies--fiction; London (England)--fiction
description: Disraeli wrote the first volume of Henrietta Temple in 1833 at the start of his affair with Henrietta Sykes, on whom the novels eponymous heroine is based, and completed it three years later, shortly after the affair had ended. The two volumes reflect these two stages of the relationship, the first with, "the rustle of real petticoats [being] more audible than in any other part of Disraeli's work," the latter where, "passion has vanished." The novel was written at a time when Disraeli was heavily in debt (ca 1m in todays terms) and its limited success helped ease Disraelis financial situation.
creator: Benjamin Disraeli

title: Cohen of Trinity
subject: Jewish Fiction--19th century; English fiction--Jewish authors; Jews--Fiction
description: Short story about a brilliant Jewish student at Trinity College, Cambridge who struggles with his identity as both a Jew and an intellectual in Victorian England. The story follows Cohen's internal conflicts as he tries to balance his academic ambitions with his Jewish heritage, ultimately depicting his isolation and alienation in the gentile academic world.
creator: Amy Levy

title: Middle-Class Jewish Women of Today
subject: Jewish women--Social conditions--19th century; Jewish women--Social life and customs--Great Britain; Marriage customs and rites--Jewish
description: This 1886 article from The Jewish Chronicle discusses the social constraints faced by middle-class Jewish women in Victorian England, particularly focusing on their limited social interactions with men, pressure to marry, and struggles to pursue education or independent lives.
creator: Amy Levy
relation: In The Jewish Chronicle, September 17, 1886, p. 7.

title: Reuben Sachs: A Sketch
subject: Jews--England--London--Fiction; London (England)--Fiction
description: A satirical examination of London's upper-middle-class Anglo-Jewish society, focusing on the ambitious young lawyer Reuben Sachs and his cousin Judith Quixano, whose mutual attraction is complicated by social pressures and Reuben's political aspirations. The novel critiques the materialistic values and social constraints of Victorian Jewish society while exploring themes of assimilation, tradition, and the conflict between personal desires and communal expectations.
creator: Amy Levy

title: The Jew in Fiction
subject: Jews--Fiction; English fiction--19th century--History and criticism; Sterotypes (Social psychology) in literature
description: An essay in The Jewish Chronicle critiquing the lack of nuanced Jewish representation in English literature of the time. Levy laments that while Jews hold prominent positions in English society, business, politics, and the arts, contemporary fiction largely relies on stereotypical portrayals like Shylock and Rebecca of York, with only a few works like "Daniel Deronda" making sincere but ultimately incomplete attempts to capture modern Jewish life and character.
creator: Amy Levy
relation: In The Jewish Chronicle, June 4, 1886, p. 13.

title: "Communings with Nature, Night"
subject: Nature--Poetry; English--literature--Jewish authors
description: "Night" explores the profound and spiritual essence of the nocturnal world. Through vivid imagery of diverse landscapes, from American forests to the African desert, the poem contemplates how night reveals divine truths and offers solace to the soul. Ultimately, it posits night as a sacred time for introspection and a pathway to understanding a higher power's unchanging love and rest.
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 2, no. 1, Apr. 1844, pp. 22-6.

title: "Communings with Nature, No. III, Hymn to Summer"
subject: Nature--Poetry; English--literature--Jewish authors
description: "Hymn to Summer" is a lyrical ode celebrating the season's beauty and its profound effect on the human spirit. The poem describes summer's vibrant life, from blooming buds to flowing streams, and reflects on the peace and joy it imparts, even amidst personal weakness and care. The narrator finds spiritual solace in summer, perceiving it as a divine presence that reminds one of God's omnipresence.
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 2, no. 5, Aug. 1844, pp. 241-42.

title: "Communings with Nature, No. IV, Autumn Leaves"
subject: Nature--Poetry; English--literature--Jewish authors
description: A poem that finds beauty and spiritual lessons in the fading glories of autumn. It describes the rich colors of the leaves as they prepare to decay, highlighting how nature, even in death, maintains loveliness and bloom. The poem interprets the leaves' journey as a message of hope and divine mercy, suggesting that just as nature is gloriously arrayed before it fades, God's love will illuminate the "valley of decay" for humanity.
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 2, no. 7, Nov. 1844, pp. 384-85.

title: "Communings with Nature, No. V, Autumn Winds"
subject: Nature--Poetry; English--literature--Jewish authors
description: The poem personifies the melancholy wailing of the autumn wind, initially questioning if it mourns nature's decay and the passing of summer. However, the wind's response reveals a deeper sorrow: it mourns not nature's temporary decline, but the blighted hopes, broken hearts, and human suffering caused by winter's harshness and lack of mutual aid.
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 3, no. 10, Jan. 1846, pp. 503-5.

title: "Communings with Nature, No. VI, The Evergreen"
subject: Nature--Poetry; English--literature--Jewish authors
description: "The Evergreen" initially portrays the evergreen as a neglected and somber plant, overlooked during spring, summer, and autumn's vibrant displays. However, the poem ultimately celebrates the evergreen for its steadfastness and resilience, particularly in winter, seeing it as an emblem of God's "omnific love" and "never-changing care."
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 4, no. 2, May 1846, 78-9.

title: "Communings with Nature, Ocean"
subject: Nature--Poetry; English--literature--Jewish authors
description: "Ocean" is a hymn that explores the speaker's multifaceted relationship with the sea, encompassing both its serene beauty under moonlight and sun, and its terrifying power during storms. Despite its destructive potential, the speaker expresses a deep love for the ocean.
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 2, no. 2, May 1844, pp. 81-2.

title: "Dialogue Stanzas: Composed for, and Repeated by, Two Dear Little Animated Girls, at a Family Celebration of the Festival of Purim"
subject: Purim--Poetry; Jewish children--Poetry; Jewish religious poetry
description: "Dialogue Stanzas" captures a conversation between two young girls celebrating Purim, balancing childlike exuberance with thoughtful reflection.
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 3, no. 5, Aug. 1845, pp. 239-40.

title: "I Never Loved a Flower"
subject: Spiritual life--Poetry; Loss (Psychology)--Poetry; Jewish poetry
description: A melancholic reflection on the fleeting nature of joy and the inevitability of loss in earthly life.
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 2, no. 9, Dec. 1844, pp. 427-28.

title: "An Infant's Smile"
subject: Infants--Poetry; God--Love--Poetry; Jewish poetry
description: A poem marveling at the pure, spontaneous joy expressed in a baby's smile.
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 3, no. 9, Dec. 1845, 440-41.

title: The Perez Family, A Tale
subject: Jewish families--Fiction; Interfaith marriage--Fiction; Jewish religious fiction
description: The narrative follows the devout Perez family as they navigate personal misfortunes and the challenges of upholding Jewish faith amidst societal pressures and the consequences of interfaith relationships. The story emphasizes divine providence, resilience, and the enduring importance of religious commitment and family loyalty.
creator: Grace Aguilar

title: "A Poet's Dying Hymn"
subject: English--literature--Jewish authors; Jewish poetry
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Voice of Jacob, 18 Feb. 1842, p. 87.

title: "Sabbath Thoughts, No. IV, Parting from Friends"
subject: Consolation--Poetry; Friendship--Poetry; Jewish religious poetry
description: "Parting from Friends" explores the profound pain of separation from loved ones, acknowledging the "bitter pang" and "rudely riven" links of the heart.
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 3, no. 8, Nov. 1845, pp. 379-80.

title: "Sabbath Thoughts Written on the Close of a Peculiarly Blessed Day of Rest"
subject: Sabbath--Poetry; Devotional poetry, Jewish; Jewish religious poetry
description: A devotional poem expressing gratitude for the spiritual solace and strength found on the day of rest.
creator: Grace Aguilar
relation: In Occident and American Jewish Advocate, vol. 1, no. 10, Jan. 1844, pp. 484-86.
